title: Translate Phrases into Algebraic Statements
kid_friendly_explainer: We can turn words into math! A letter (like $x$) stands for an unknown number.
Key words tell us which operation to use: plus, minus, times, or divide.
Pay attention to order! "Five less than x" means $x - 5$ (not $5 - x$).
Use parentheses for grouped phrases like "sum of..." or "product of...".
Remember: "of" usually means multiply, especially with percents like "30% of $n$ = $0.30n$".

core_rules.name: Addition Keywords
core_rules.plain_english: Words like sum, plus, more than, increased by, and total all mean addition (+).

core_rules.name: Subtraction Keywords
core_rules.plain_english: Words like minus, difference, decreased by, and less than all mean subtraction (-).

core_rules.name: Multiplication Keywords
core_rules.plain_english: Words like times, product, of, twice, and thrice all mean multiplication (×).

core_rules.name: Division Keywords
core_rules.plain_english: Words like quotient, divided by, per, and ratio of all mean division (÷).

core_rules.name: Order Matters!
core_rules.plain_english: "a less than b" means b - a (reverse the order). "Subtract a from b" also means b - a.
core_rules.latex: \text{"a less than b"} = b - a \quad \text{(not } a - b\text{)}

core_rules.name: Grouping with Parentheses
core_rules.plain_english: Phrases like "sum of..." or "difference of..." need parentheses. Example: twice the sum of x and 5 is 2(x + 5).

step_by_step_examples.problem_latex: \text{Twelve times the sum of 5 and } x
walkthrough: Start with the inner phrase: "sum of 5 and \(x\)" means \(5 + x\).
Put this sum in parentheses: \((5 + x)\).
"Twelve times" this sum means multiply by 12.
"A number" can be represented by \(x\) (or any variable).

easy.directions: Write an expression or equation. Use $x$ if the number is not named.

medium.directions: Watch the order and use parentheses for grouped words like "sum of...".

items.hint: Sum needs parentheses: (x + 5), then multiply by 2
"Difference of A and B" means A - B

challenge.directions: Multi-part phrases; include percents and rates.

items.question_latex: \text{Five more than the quotient of } x \text{ and } 3
\text{Half of the sum of } p \text{ and } q

items.hint: Three times n = 3n, then subtract from 8

items.question_latex: \text{The ratio of } a \text{ to } b \text{ minus } 4
items.hint: Ratio a to b is a/b, then subtract 4

extreme.directions: Tricky order words, nested groups, and inequalities.

items.question_latex: \text{Three less than the product of } 5 \text{ and the sum of } x \text{ and } 2
items.hint: Work inside out: sum (x+2), then product with 5, then subtract 3
"At least" means ≥; expression is 3p + 7 (if comparing to value k: 3p + 7 ≥ k)

items.question_latex: \text{The number } x \text{ is } 5 \text{ less than three times } y
items.hint: Three times y = 3y, five less than that = 3y - 5, equals x

teacher_notes: Emphasize that ORDER MATTERS with subtraction and division. "5 less than x" is $x - 5$, not $5 - x$.
Teach students to identify grouped phrases that need parentheses: "sum of", "difference of", "product of", "quotient of".
"Of" almost always means multiply, especially with fractions and percents: "half of x" = $\frac{1}{2}x$, "20% of n" = $0.20n$.
Practice "less than" and "more than" extensively, as these commonly cause confusion with order.
When translating to equations, the word "is" or "equals" becomes the equals sign.
Inequality words: "at least" (≥), "at most" (≤), "fewer than" (<), "greater than" (>), "no more than" (≤), "no less than" (≥).
